descriptionSet.description: Woman in Sari, with open hair, sitting by a small water canal, with one foot in the water. Next to her is a basket of vegetables, in one hand, she holds a white radish, her chin rests on the other hand. she looks smilingly at a viewer outside the frame. The field on which she sits has been harvested, the ones in the back are still green. other farmers work on the fields, a water pump spills water into the canal. hills, trees and some huts covered with straw mats can be seen.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

titleSet.title: A woman sitting by a canal in a field

hra:item.hra:value: Studio H. R. Raja

description-en: Woman in Sari, with open hair, sitting by a small water canal, with one foot in the water. Next to her is a basket of vegetables, in one hand, she holds a white radish, her chin rests on the other hand. she looks smilingly at a viewer outside the frame. The field on which she sits has been harvested, the ones in the back are still green. other farmers work on the fields, a water pump spills water into the canal. hills, trees and some huts covered with straw mats can be seen.
text-en: STUDIO H. R. Raja.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The woman looks more like an 'item girl' from a Bollywood dance scene than an 'authentic' farmer. But this is probably exactly what the image plays on and with: exoticised stereotypes of the rural woman, earthly, seductive, beautiful and naturally-erotic. Radish and water play on the erotic symbolics. Kajri Jain, Sumathi Ramaswamy and Patricia Uberoi have written on this gendered iconography of 'mother India' (Christiane Brosius)(cb)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In posters of rural landscapes, buxom farm girls reap rich harvests made possible by the modern tractors, threshing machines and irrigation pumps; here work surrounds and gives meaning to the village beauty, making her, as Patricia Uberoi has argued, a sensuous evocation of Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and fertility. In images of the modern home, by contrast, work has disappeared. The promise seems to be that the mistress of a modern house is not unduly occupied by that work; she either has servants carefully out of sight, or housekeeping has become so effortless as to take up little of her time. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)
